question: Question_Section_201_06_(b)
statement:
Consider the same graph as in the
\href{Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH307/April_2013/Question_Section_201_05_(a)}{previous
question}, now interpreted as an internet where the vertices represent
web pages and the arrows represent links.

\begin{description}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item[]
\includegraphics[width=.5\textwidth]{MATH307April2013Section201Q6.png}
\end{description}

\textbf{(b)} What is the stochastic matrix associated with the PageRank
algorithm with damping factor \emph{α = 1/2}. What happens to the
eigenvalues as \emph{α} tends to \emph{0} (complete damping)?
sols:
The stochastic matrix for a damped system is

\begin{align*}
S &= (1 - \alpha)Q + \alpha P
\\ &= \frac{1}{2}Q + \frac{1}{2}P
\\ &= \begin{bmatrix}
1/12 & 1/12 & 1/12 & 1/12 & 1/12 & 1/6
\\ 1/3 & 1/12 & 1/12 & 1/12 & 1/12 & 1/6
\\ 1/12 & 1/3 & 1/12 & 1/12 & 1/12 & 1/6
\\ 1/3 & 1/12 & 1/12 & 1/12 & 1/12 & 1/6
\\ 1/12 & 1/3 & 1/12 & 7/12 & 1/12 & 1/6
\\ 1/12 & 1/12 & 7/12 & 1/12 & 7/12 & 1/6
\end{bmatrix}\end{align*}

When the damping factor $\displaystyle \alpha$ tends to zero, the
eigenvalues of \emph{S} tend to \emph{Q}. Because \emph{Q} projects onto
a 1 dimension subspace, there is one eigenvalue equal to 1, and the rest
are zero.
